hello!, articles = ['Depressed clients often struggle with their ability to think positively and to generate potential solutions to their problems (Priester and Clum 1993). Throughout most therapy sessions, the therapist can help clients to expand their view of life, self, skills, abilities, resources, and coping options. Questions can be used to help clients per- ceive a problem situation in terms of their interpretations, expectations, emotional reactions, and intuitions (Li et al. 2008). It can be helpful to ask clients to view a problem in terms of future possibilities (Chatjoulis and Humphreys 2007) so they can shift from a focus on past troubles and begin to see the situation improving over time.
Therapy can help clients learn to identify new coping actions that might help to resolve a problem situation. Clients can learn to change what they do when confronted with a difficult situation. Useful questions include: ‘‘How do you want things to change?’’; ‘‘What specifically could be changed here?’’; ‘‘What do you do — How do you respond when the problem develops?’’; ‘‘How often does the problem occur?’’; ‘‘What makes this situation a prob- lem?’’; ‘‘From your perspective, how bad does it get?’’; ‘‘What would happen if you did nothing?’’; ‘‘What do you typically do when you are feeling really down?’’; ‘‘What else could you try?’’; ‘‘Have you ever found anything that seemed to help the problem get better?’’; ‘‘Are there times when the problem goes away completely?’’; ‘‘If a similar problem happened to your best friend, what advice would you give to her?’’. Several of these questions imply there are other options available to the client, while nonetheless remaining open to any idea that might be generated by the client.
When helping clients to generate a range of coping options, it is important to focus on the quantity, not the quality of options that are generated. When working to generate new options, clients may need help to set aside habitual tendencies and social convention in order to broaden their alternatives. Negative attitudes and critical remarks tend to impair the creativity process. Nondirective questions can be more effective than leading questions. Some questions do not really search for new information but include an implied direction (e.g., ‘‘Could you try confronting your boss in a more direct way?’’). Many leading questions imply ‘‘I think you should do X’’. Too often, therapists rely on a structured and dogmatic style of therapy. It can be much faster to tell clients about the coping strategy selected by the expert therapist. Unfortu- nately, a directive approach can turn the client into a pas- sive recipient. The client may behave like a student in a coping-skills course. Therapy is more likely to map onto the client’s natural talents, penchants, and abilities if the coping options derive from the client’s own vision of the problem and its solution. Thus, it may be better to ask ‘‘What else could you do to deal with this situation?’’ or ‘‘What could you do to make this situation better between you and your neighbor?’’ so as to encourage clients to think of their own solutions.
Therapy can help clients learn to identify new attitudes that might help to reduce their emotional reactions and focus on adaptive responses. Clients can learn to change their attitudes and expectations related to specific situa- tions. Questions can be used to help clients identify and
challenge the assumptions behind their dysfunctional beliefs (Brookfield 1987). Therapy can help guide clients as they brainstorm a wide variety of new coping options. Ideas for coping can be based on past attempts to cope with similar problems, whether or not they had been successful. Useful questions include: ‘‘Have you ever had a problem like this before?’’; ‘‘How did you deal with it then?’’; ‘‘How well did that plan work out?’’; ‘‘How well do you think a similar plan might work for you now?’’; ‘‘Has there ever been a time when you were able to handle this situ- ation and feel good about it?’’; ‘‘What else was going on in your life at that time?’’; ‘‘What kind of things have you already tried?’’; ‘‘Tell me about something you have thought about doing but never tried’’. A series of questions can help clients to search for new potential solutions to a difficult problem situation.
Effective therapy relies on the therapist’s ability to help each client generate new, unique coping options for man- aging their upsetting life situations. New coping options can be based on role models from family members, friends, or even celebrities. Specific questions can be used to help clients identify possible options based on assorted role models. For example, ‘‘Have you ever seen someone else successfully manage a problem like this before?’’; ‘‘How did they deal with it?’’; ‘‘What do you think (your mother, father, brother, sister) would say about it?’’; ‘‘What would your best friend do to deal with this type of problem?’’; ‘‘Who is the funniest person you know — ‘‘How would s/he deal with a problem like this?’’; ‘‘Who is the most assertive person you know?’’; ‘‘Just speculating, but how do you think (insert the name of a famous comedian or action movie hero) might deal with a situation like this?; ‘‘How do you think (name a comic book character or a superhero) would deal with this situation?’’. Questions can help clients to move away from their own limited view of the problems and begin to see a wide range of coping options.
New coping options can be based on personal values, goals, or ideal standards. Questions can include: ‘‘What could you do to deal with this situation?’’; ‘‘How would you like to deal with this situation the next time it hap- pens?’’; ‘‘If you set aside all worries, how would you handle this situation?’’. Even outrageous questions may help to encourage creative problem-solving. For example, clients can be asked ‘‘If you suddenly had super-human powers, what might you be able to do to handle this situ- ation?’’; ‘‘If we had a crystal ball that let us see into the future, a time when the problem had been resolved, what do you see that had made the difference?’’; ‘‘If I brought in a magic wand and made the problem go away, what would we need to make happen?’’. The goal is to help clients shift away from their habitual way of responding and begin to approach problems with a more creative view.
It is important to avoid using too many questions that could make the session feel like an interrogation. A general exploratory question, such as ‘‘What other ways could you approach this situation?’’, should be asked only once to avoid annoying the client. However, the same question can be rephrased as ‘‘I wonder if you have really tried all of your options’’. Furthermore the same issue can be broad- ened through a variety of simple changes; ‘‘What do you want to do?’’; ‘‘Is there anything you think might be helpful to try but you have been afraid of trying?’’; ‘‘Is there anything you wish you knew how to do so you could try it here?’’; ‘‘Is there anything you wish you had the courage to try?’’. Each of these variations posed a different perspective and thereby can elicit a different answer from the client.', 'After the client has identified new coping options and selected the most viable plan for managing a difficult sit- uation, many clients still benefit from additional structure and guidance in order to implement the desired changes. Many clients remain reluctant to change, even if the plan makes sense. It is often important to try to anticipate potential obstacles, road blocks, detours, and excuses that might derail the plans. Sometimes, role-played interactions during the session can be used to help clients anticipate the situation and then implement the changes. Also, it can be useful to differentiate reluctance (e.g., ‘‘I’ll try’’) from sincere determination (e.g., ‘‘I can do it’’).
A thoughtful series of questions can help clients to prepare in a variety of ways. During the implementation stage, useful questions include: ‘‘So where should things go from here?’’; ‘‘What do you plan to do now?’’; ‘‘Based on our discussion, when will you tackle this situation?’’; ‘‘What will you do differently than your usual way of responding?’’; ‘‘What might be a good first step to take this week?’’; ‘‘What could we aim to accomplish this week?’’; ‘‘How do you expect the other people will react when you behave that way?’’; ‘‘What can you do to remain calm and focused?’’; ‘‘When was the last time you felt confident in your ability to deal with a problem like this?’’; ‘‘What was most helpful back then?’’; ‘‘Is there anything else we can do now to help you prepare for it?’’; ‘‘Would it help if we role-played it right now?’’; ‘‘What do you expect to be the hardest part of your plan?’’; ‘‘What is the difference between ‘I want to do it’ versus ‘I should do it’?’’. When a clear plan can be envisioned, clients are more likely to implement the new coping strategies.
After a plan has been implemented, therapy dialogue can focus on an objective evaluation of recent coping efforts. As part of the evaluation process, useful questions include: ‘‘How well did the plan go?’’; ‘‘Did things go better or worse than you had expected?’’; ‘‘What do you feel you were able to do quite well?’’; ‘‘What do you wish you had done differently?’’; ‘‘Is there anything else that you could have done differently?’’; ‘‘Are there some things that still need to be changed?’’. Many problems are either chronic or recurrent in nature, so it becomes useful to help
clients to continue to evaluate and prepare for the next time a problem occurs. Recent coping efforts can help to guide future coping. When the recent coping has gone well, cli- ents can remember and re-implement a similar strategy in the future. When recent coping efforts have been less than successful, clients can examine the strategies, explore specific parameters, and hopefully devise new strategies that might be more effective.
Many difficult situations benefit from a bit of advance planning. Clients can learn to look ahead to the future in order to plan for continued improvements in dealing with similar difficulties. To help clients prepare for future problems, useful questions include: ‘‘What can you learn from these recent events?’’; ‘‘The next time a problem like this occurs, how will you deal with it then?’’; ‘‘What strategies are working out well and which ones should be changed?’’; ‘‘If you are confronted with a similar problem 10 years from now, how will you handle it then?’’; ‘‘What advice might you give to someone who is just starting out on the same similar path you were on 6 months ago?’’. Throughout the dialogue, there is a subtle emphasis on the life-long process of problem-solving as a basic coping skill.', 'Cognitive therapy and problem-solving therapy provide useful theoretical and practical frameworks to guide ther- apy sessions. However, there is a risk that therapy sessions may become overly structured by treatment manuals, an emphasis on psycho-educational training, and the use of bibliotherapy as homework. In contrast, process issues like guided discovery, collaborative empiricism, and the Socratic method can help to guide the interactive flow of psychotherapy sessions (Overholser 2011). To be most effective, the therapist must remain aware of psychother- apy process issues. Changing topics too abruptly can be disorienting for clients. To counter this problem and avoid creating the feel of an interrogation, the therapist can ‘‘package’’ questions within a gentle frame. For example, before changing topics, the therapist may interrupt the client and state: ‘‘Let me jump topics a minute, if that would be okay’’. Such preliminary statements can show respect for the client and the issues that have been discussed.
Problem-solving therapy provides a useful framework to structure the content of therapy sessions. However, a didactic approach to therapy is laced with direct guidance and advice that may create a dependency on the therapist (Thompson 1983). Even when the therapist uses questions to guide the flow of therapy, certain questions can implicitly steer the client down a predetermined path (Lakin 1988). The ultimate goal of therapy is to promote independence and autonomy in the client, usually by helping clients to discover their own solutions (Van Hoose and Kottler 1985). A collaborative process helps to pro- mote self-determination in clients (Tee and Kazantzis 2011).
The Socratic method helps to organize the process of the therapeutic dialogue (Overholser 2010). Questions can be used to encourage the client’s self-monitoring and self- evaluation of relevant problem areas (see Fig. 1). When the evaluation determines the situation does not meet the cli- ent’s goals, the client can focus on strategies for problem solving. A Socratic inquiry uses a dialogue process that helps clients learn the questions to ask in order to guide their own process of inquiry and self-discovery (Glaser 1984). Each question moves the dialogue one step further along the process of exploration, discovery, and problem- solving. The process of questioning can become internal- ized so that clients can continue to think through the stages of problem-solving when confronted with common stress- ful life events. The goal is not to solve the client’s prob- lems, but to cultivate rational thinking and creative problem-solving skills in the client (Overholser 1996).
Despite the potential value of questions used to guide therapy discussions, it remains important for the therapist to be selective in the number and type of questions that are asked (Overholser 1993). Questions can be interspersed with an empathetic response to reduce the interrogative nature of the dialogue (Milliren et al. 2007). Each question should have a clear therapeutic purpose (Overholser 1993). Experienced therapists learn to suppress the automatic reactions that sometimes are elicited from the social con- ventions that guide casual conversations (e.g., replying‘‘Congratulations’’ when female client says she just learned that she is pregnant). Instead, therapists should preview each question by anticipating in what way the client’s answer will help to move therapy forward (Dillon 1990).
Guided discovery plays a central role in the Socratic method of psychotherapy. When using guided discovery, it is useful to view the therapist as a guide, analogous to an experienced fishing guide who knows the land and water terrain, is familiar with the types of fish commonly found in the area, and knows the best bait to use and the proper depth at which to catch the fish. Furthermore, a good guide lets the customer: select the type of fish to try to catch, cast the line, and reel in the fish even if it might slip off the line. However, the guide ensures the customer’s safety, and makes sure they avoid dangerous waters. In guided dis- covery, the therapist knows the psyche and cognitive pro- cess, is familiar with most types of psychological problems, and knows the best strategies for uncovering and confronting psychosocial problems. Furthermore, a good therapist lets the client: select the problem to be con- fronted, identify the critical issues involved in the problem, and select the best plan for change even if it might not work smoothly. However, the therapist ensures the client’s safety and avoids topics or strategies that could be dan- gerous. The therapist gives the client much of the respon- sibility for seeking, exploring, and confronting the topics that are discussed in session. The therapist is familiar with common problems, useful strategies, and the most pro- ductive topics to be discussed. However, the therapist allows the client the authority to make many of the deci- sions that guide therapy.
It is useful to focus on discovery as a search for some- thing new and previously unknown or untested, so as to discover an important idea or strategy. Even though ther- apy can move at a faster pace when the therapist accepts the role of expert or teacher, therapy can become narrowly focused and overly directive. Clients are less likely to learn new ideas, remember what has been covered, or value the new information that was presented in a more didactic and dogmatic presentation. Clients learn new strategies and sometimes learn from their own mistakes. A therapist can re-direct clients as needed, to avoid dangerous situations. Guided discovery lies at the core of the process used in the Socratic method of psychotherapy.

The hallmark of strategy training is its delineation between the therapist’s role and the participant’s role in the rehabilitation process. Therapists assume a role of guided discovery,3 systematically facilitating participants’ learn- ing through prompts and questions rather than directly
instructing participants. In doing so, therapists guide par- ticipants, allowing participants to learn through their expe- riences. Through strategy training, participants learn to work through or work around specific problems in selected daily activities. In addition, participants learn how to apply the process to novel activities and situations, with the goal of promoting additional recovery of independence with daily activities long after rehabilitation is completed.
1University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, PA, USA
2Rotman Research Institute at Baycrest, Toronto, Ontario, Canada
3University of Toronto, Toronto, Ontario, Canada
4Western Psychiatric Institute & Clinic, Pittsburgh, PA, USA
Corresponding Author:
Elizabeth Skidmore, Department of Occupational Therapy, University of Pittsburgh, 5012 Forbes Tower, Pittsburgh, PA 15260, USA.
Email: skidmore@pitt.edu
Strategy training has been examined in a variety of clini- cal populations (eg, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, learning disability, major depressive disorder, acquired brain injury) as an intervention to address a variety of clinical out- comes (eg, independence, productivity, self-regulation).4-10 Originally conceived as a method for self-monitoring,11 strat- egy training has been examined as an intervention for teach- ing problem-solving skills.12,13 In fact, selected studies suggest that strategy training helps adults with acquired brain injury (ie, stroke, traumatic brain injury) reduce disabil- ity,1,2,14,15 and may even address some of the cognitive sequelae, particularly impairments in executive cognitive functions, associated with acquired brain injury.16,17
These studies have examined strategy training in clinical populations with stable behavioral and cognitive symp- toms, including individuals with acquired brain injury in the chronic phase of recovery. However, there are compelling reasons to suspect that strategy training administered in the acute phase of recovery may have a robust effect on long- term outcomes. Experience-dependent synaptic changes that occur in the acute phase are likely to shape subsequent trajectories of recovery.18,19 These trajectories of recovery establish patterns of behavior, or habits, that are difficult to change.20 This is important because even small to moderate improvements in behavior can substantially reduce care- giver burden and health care costs.21,22 Furthermore, reha- bilitation programs that have the potential to shape biological and behavioral patterns of recovery are most accessible during the acute phase of recovery. Combined, these factors support early intervention.
We previously examined the rationale for and feasibility of strategy training in adults with acute cognitive impair- ments after acquired brain injury (specifically, adults with stroke).1,2,23 The purpose of this pilot study was to obtain preliminary data estimating the effect of strategy training, relative to an attention control condition, in the acute phase of recovery after stroke. The primary aim was to estimate the effect of strategy training on activities of daily living outcomes. The secondary aim was to explore the effects of strategy training on selected measures of executive cogni- tive functions. Our intent was to use these pilot data, and our experiences, to inform the design of future larger scale clinical trials examining the efficacy of strategy training in acute rehabilitation.', 'We conducted a single-blind randomized Phase II pilot study examining strategy training among adults with cogni- tive impairments after acute stroke. We approached con- secutive admissions to inpatient rehabilitation and obtained written informed consent from the individual, if cognitive status permitted, or from a proxy, consistent with approved institutional review board procedures.
We screened participants for the following criteria: (a) primary diagnosis of acute stroke; (b) impairment of cogni- tive functions (Quick Executive Interview 3);24,25 (c) absence of severe aphasia (Boston Diagnostic Aphasia Examination Severity Rating Scale 1);26 (d) absence of dementia diagnosis (indicated in the medical record); (e) absence of current major depressive disorder, bipolar, or psychotic disorder (Primary Care Evaluation of Mental Disorders);27 (f) absence of drug and alcohol abuse within 3 months (Mini-International Neuropsychiatric Interview);28 and (g) anticipated length of stay greater than 5 days. Participants who provided consent and were eligible were randomized to intervention groups (strategy training, atten- tion control) using a simple randomization scheme derived from a random number table (1:1 ratio).', 'We collected demographic (age, gender, race) and medical information (stroke onset, type, hemisphere) from the medi- cal record at study admission. We characterized stroke severity with the National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale30 and comorbid medical burden severity with the Cumulative Illness Rating Scale.31
Trained and reliable raters who were masked to study intent and design administered a standardized measure of activities of daily living and a battery of neuropsychologi- cal tests at baseline, 3 months, and 6 months later. The pri- mary outcome measure, the Functional Independence Measure, was administered at study admission, inpatient rehabilitation discharge, 3 months after study admission, and 6 months after study admission.32 We selected this mea- sure because it is the industry standard for assessing activi- ties of daily living outcomes in acute inpatient rehabilitation populations.
The secondary outcome measure, the Color Word Interference Test from the Delis–Kaplan Executive Functioning System, was used to assess selected executive cognitive functions.33 Specifically, we examined the scaled scores from the inhibition subscale (Condition 3) and the cognitive flexibility (switching) subscale (Condition 4). We selected these subscales because they measure 2 domains of executive cognitive functions that are likely to be influenced by strategy training. Inhibition, or the pro- cess of ignoring irrelevant stimuli to complete a task, may be influenced through self-monitoring and self-evaluation
processes inherent in strategy training. Cognitive flexibility, or the ability to hold more than one concept in mind, and switch between concepts, may be influenced through itera- tive application and revision of the global strategy. The Color Word Interference Test is valid and reliable and has demonstrated sufficient psychometric performance in adults with stroke.33 For this study, we used the revised scoring procedures for the inhibition subscale. (Unpublished stan- dardization data from the Delis–Kaplan Executive Function System. Copyright ©, 2013, 2001 NCS Pearson, Inc. Used with permission. All rights reserved.)']

Introduction to Problem-Solving in Therapy Hello Aviv Eliyahu! It's great to see your enthusiasm for learning about therapy techniques. Let's explore how we can effectively guide clients in generating coping strategies. How do you think asking the right questions can influence a client's ability to find solutions?
Understanding the Client's Perspective Clients often struggle to see beyond their immediate problems. What do you think might happen if we encourage them to view their issues in terms of future possibilities?
Generating Coping Options When helping clients generate coping options, it's crucial to focus on quantity over quality. Why do you think this approach might be beneficial?
1. Encourage clients to brainstorm without judgment. 2. Ask open-ended questions like, "What else could you try?" 3. Help them set aside habitual responses to broaden their thinking.
Using the Socratic Method The Socratic method can be a powerful tool in therapy. How do you think guiding clients through questions can help them discover their own solutions rather than relying on your expertise?
1. Use questions that promote self-reflection, such as, "What do you typically do when facing this problem?" 2. Encourage clients to think about their past experiences and how they managed similar situations. 3. Help them identify role models and ask, "How would someone you admire handle this?"
Implementing New Strategies Once clients have identified potential coping strategies, they may still need support to implement them. What steps do you think we should take to help them overcome reluctance to change?
1. Anticipate obstacles and discuss them openly. 2. Role-play scenarios to prepare for real-life applications. 3. Differentiate between reluctance and determination by asking, "What do you plan to do now?"
Evaluating Coping Efforts After implementing a plan, it's essential to evaluate its effectiveness. What questions could you ask to facilitate this evaluation process?
1. "How well did the plan go?" 2. "What do you wish you had done differently?" 3. "What strategies worked well, and which need adjustment?"
Planning for Future Challenges Looking ahead is vital for continuous improvement. How can we help clients prepare for future problems based on their recent experiences?
1. Encourage them to reflect on what they've learned. 2. Ask, "How will you handle a similar problem in the future?" 3. Discuss strategies that worked and those that should be changed.
By using these techniques, we can empower clients to become more independent and confident in their problem-solving abilities. What do you think is the most important takeaway from this discussion?

what is my name?, articles = ['It can be helpful to view a stressful situation as a problem that can be solved. Some problems jump quickly into cli- ents’ lives, while other problems slowly creep in one day at a time. Clients can learn to recognize a problem when it first occurs and label it appropriately as a problem that needs to be confronted. Extreme terms like ‘‘horrible’’, ‘‘terrible’’, and ‘‘catastrophe’’ are dangerous because there are very few situations that deserve such extreme labels and it becomes more difficult to approach a problem when it has been magnified by a dramatic label.
A therapeutic dialogue can help clients to understand their problems and clarify their goals. Therapy aims to avoid vague problems (e.g., ‘‘Life is not worth living’’) and unrealistic goals (e.g., ‘‘I wish things could be back the way they used to be’’). Questions can be used to clarify specific details such as the frequency, intensity, and duration of the problematic events. Implicitly, clients learn to become more objective and less reactive when confronted with common problems. It is important to clarify the desired goals and relevant sub-goals related to the resolution of the problem. It is often helpful to subdivide a problem into several smaller units (Nickerson 1994). Many life problems become intertwined. Thus, loss of a job creates financial problems that often trigger conflict in the home. The problem may be split into several components, and each smaller problem can be prioritized. With help, clients can learn to separate problems at work from conflict at home. If problems blend together, it quickly feels overwhelming and seems impossible to solve.
Before trying to solve a problem, it can be useful to gather information about the problem and its occurrence in an effort to identify possible causal factors. Useful ques- tions include: ‘‘How long have these things been going on?’’; ‘‘Tell me about the last time it happened’’; ‘‘When this situation develops, how long does it last?’’; ‘‘Lately, has it changed in its frequency or intensity?’’. Furthermore, it is important for the therapist to understand the client’s life situation, subjective reactions, and feelings of distress. Effective therapy relies on empathy and a compassionate understanding from a professional who shares the client’s views. The therapist needs to work from within the client’s subjective phenomenological experience. Psycho- therapy sessions are different from conversations with a supportive friend or a telephone call to a radio talk show therapist. The process of therapy requires patience, per- sistence, and sincere willingness to understand the key events from the client’s perspective. Therapeutic discus- sions can help clients begin their search for potential causes and possible solutions.
Questions can be used to gather detailed information about the client’s recent symptoms. Clients may be guided to track their symptoms in five distinct domains: affect reactions (e.g., periods of sadness or irritability), behavior changes (e.g., limited activity, inability to perform daily chores), cognitions (persistent worries, pessimistic expec- tations, self-blame), social functioning (e.g., recent argu- ments, social isolation), and somatic manifestations (e.g., loss of appetite, disturbance of sleep). Using questions to assess each domain can ensure that both therapist and client will thoroughly review the problem and its effects. Ques- tions can be used to guide the flow of the session, so that important issues are expanded in detail and irrelevant topics are condensed (Pozner and Dodd 1993).
An important aspect of therapy involves helping clients to determine which problems need to be confronted and which problems can be tolerated or ignored. It can be useful to help clients view most of their problems as minor annoyances instead of major catastrophes. Clients can be asked ‘‘Is this really a life-changing event or could you be magnifying the damage here?’’; ‘‘Would it be better to work on repairing this relationship or to cut your losses and move toward ending it?’’. However, the therapist must be careful to avoid invalidating the client’s subjective distress. Useful questions may aim to normalize the situation and emphasize tolerance instead of distress. Even simple rating questions may help to reframe the client’s perspective (e.g., ‘‘How much is this a problem you can solve versus a sit- uation you could learn to accept?; ‘‘On a scale from zero to 100, where zero means not a problem at all and 100 might be a rating for individuals who survived a natural disaster that destroyed much of the area, just how bad is your situation?’’).
Clients can learn to identify the relevant issues arising in the current situation and re-evaluate the perceived magni- tude of the problem. When exploring the definition of a problem, useful questions include: ‘‘What do you see as the main problem?’’; ‘‘How serious or dangerous is this prob- lem?’’; ‘‘Is this a life-changing problem or could it be seen as an annoying inconvenience?’’; ‘‘What exactly do you find most upsetting?’’; ‘‘What makes this situation such a major problem?’’; ‘‘What other ways could you look at this situation?’’. Therapeutic dialogue can aim to identify spe- cific and realistic goals for the resolution of the problem. The therapist may ask a series of questions to guide the process (e.g., ‘‘What might be a successful outcome here?’’; ‘‘What would you hope to accomplish here?’’). Questions can help clients to focus on the most useful and relevant aspects of a problem situation.
Therapeutic questions can reduce the client’s tendency to attribute blame onto self or others. In almost all situa- tions, it is helpful to appreciate the numerous factors that are involved in the cause of most problems. Useful ques- tions include: ‘‘What do you think is causing the prob- lem?’’; ‘‘Have you considered other possible causes?’’; ‘‘What else might be involved here?’’; ‘‘What role might you have played in creating this problem?’’; ‘‘Tell me about the first time the problem happened.’’; ‘‘Have you noticed anything that seems to trigger the problem?’’; ‘‘Does the problem seem more likely to occur if you are already in a bad mood or does your mood have no effect on things?’’; ‘‘What about if you are physically fatigued?’’; ‘‘What if you have been feeling ill?’’. An objective appraisal of possible causal pathways can help to shift the client’s focus onto useful and malleable factors.
Therapists should avoid asking the prototypical therapy question ‘‘How did that make you feel?’’ because it implies an incorrect causal path. Events do not cause moods. No other person can make the client feel depressed, angry, or insecure. Clients often make claims such as ‘‘my wife made me so angry’’. Instead, moods can be used to identify situations that need to be changed. Clients can be asked ‘‘What do you usually do when you are feeling really sad? What could you do differently to manage those emo- tions?’’. It is usually helpful to realize that irrational beliefs cause negative moods. Useful questions include: ‘‘What was it like for you when you saw this situation develop- ing?’’; ‘‘What were you feeling at that time?’’; ‘‘What goes through your head when the problem begins?’’; ‘‘What is another way of looking at this situation?’’; ‘‘How could you tell if your view is right or wrong?’’; ‘‘Where is the evi- dence to support your view?’’. Questions can help to push the client to assess the source of the information, examine the validity of the evidence, and evaluate the chosen goals for overcoming a difficult situation.', 'Depressed clients often struggle with their ability to think positively and to generate potential solutions to their problems (Priester and Clum 1993). It can be helpful to ask clients to view a problem in terms of future possibilities (Chatjoulis and Humphreys 2007) so they can shift from a focus on past troubles and begin to see the situation improving over time.
Therapy can help clients learn to identify new coping actions that might help to resolve a problem situation. Clients can learn to change what they do when confronted with a difficult situation. Useful questions include: ‘‘How do you want things to change?’’; ‘‘What specifically could be changed here?’’; ‘‘What do you do — How do you respond when the problem develops?’’; ‘‘How often does the problem occur?’’; ‘‘What makes this situation a prob- lem?’’; ‘‘From your perspective, how bad does it get?’’; ‘‘What would happen if you did nothing?’’; ‘‘What do you typically do when you are feeling really down?’’; ‘‘What else could you try?’’; ‘‘Have you ever found anything that seemed to help the problem get better?’’; ‘‘Are there times when the problem goes away completely?’’; ‘‘If a similar problem happened to your best friend, what advice would you give to her?’’. Several of these questions imply there are other options available to the client, while nonetheless remaining open to any idea that might be generated by the client.
When helping clients to generate a range of coping options, it is important to focus on the quantity, not the quality of options that are generated. When working to generate new options, clients may need help to set aside habitual tendencies and social convention in order to broaden their alternatives. Negative attitudes and critical remarks tend to impair the creativity process. Nondirective questions can be more effective than leading questions. Some questions do not really search for new information but include an implied direction (e.g., ‘‘Could you try confronting your boss in a more direct way?’’). Many leading questions imply ‘‘I think you should do X’’. Too often, therapists rely on a structured and dogmatic style of therapy. It can be much faster to tell clients about the coping strategy selected by the expert therapist. Unfortu- nately, a directive approach can turn the client into a pas- sive recipient. The client may behave like a student in a coping-skills course. Therapy is more likely to map onto the client’s natural talents, penchants, and abilities if the coping options derive from the client’s own vision of the problem and its solution. Thus, it may be better to ask ‘‘What else could you do to deal with this situation?’’ or ‘‘What could you do to make this situation better between you and your neighbor?’’ so as to encourage clients to think of their own solutions.
Therapy can help clients learn to identify new attitudes that might help to reduce their emotional reactions and focus on adaptive responses. Clients can learn to change their attitudes and expectations related to specific situa- tions. Questions can be used to help clients identify and
challenge the assumptions behind their dysfunctional beliefs (Brookfield 1987). Therapy can help guide clients as they brainstorm a wide variety of new coping options. Ideas for coping can be based on past attempts to cope with similar problems, whether or not they had been successful. Useful questions include: ‘‘Have you ever had a problem like this before?’’; ‘‘How did you deal with it then?’’; ‘‘How well did that plan work out?’’; ‘‘How well do you think a similar plan might work for you now?’’; ‘‘Has there ever been a time when you were able to handle this situ- ation and feel good about it?’’; ‘‘What else was going on in your life at that time?’’; ‘‘What kind of things have you already tried?’’; ‘‘Tell me about something you have thought about doing but never tried’’. A series of questions can help clients to search for new potential solutions to a difficult problem situation.
Effective therapy relies on the therapist’s ability to help each client generate new, unique coping options for man- aging their upsetting life situations. New coping options can be based on role models from family members, friends, or even celebrities. Specific questions can be used to help clients identify possible options based on assorted role models. For example, ‘‘Have you ever seen someone else successfully manage a problem like this before?’’; ‘‘How did they deal with it?’’; ‘‘What do you think (your mother, father, brother, sister) would say about it?’’; ‘‘What would your best friend do to deal with this type of problem?’’; ‘‘Who is the funniest person you know — ‘‘How would s/he deal with a problem like this?’’; ‘‘Who is the most assertive person you know?’’; ‘‘Just speculating, but how do you think (insert the name of a famous comedian or action movie hero) might deal with a situation like this?; ‘‘How do you think (name a comic book character or a superhero) would deal with this situation?’’. Questions can help clients to move away from their own limited view of the problems and begin to see a wide range of coping options.
New coping options can be based on personal values, goals, or ideal standards. Questions can include: ‘‘What could you do to deal with this situation?’’; ‘‘How would you like to deal with this situation the next time it hap- pens?’’; ‘‘If you set aside all worries, how would you handle this situation?’’. Even outrageous questions may help to encourage creative problem-solving. For example, clients can be asked ‘‘If you suddenly had super-human powers, what might you be able to do to handle this situ- ation?’’; ‘‘If we had a crystal ball that let us see into the future, a time when the problem had been resolved, what do you see that had made the difference?’’; ‘‘If I brought in a magic wand and made the problem go away, what would we need to make happen?’’. The goal is to help clients shift away from their habitual way of responding and begin to approach problems with a more creative view.
It is important to avoid using too many questions that could make the session feel like an interrogation. A general exploratory question, such as ‘‘What other ways could you approach this situation?’’, should be asked only once to avoid annoying the client. However, the same question can be rephrased as ‘‘I wonder if you have really tried all of your options’’. Furthermore the same issue can be broad- ened through a variety of simple changes; ‘‘What do you want to do?’’; ‘‘Is there anything you think might be helpful to try but you have been afraid of trying?’’; ‘‘Is there anything you wish you knew how to do so you could try it here?’’; ‘‘Is there anything you wish you had the courage to try?’’. Each of these variations posed a different perspective and thereby can elicit a different answer from the client.', 'After a variety of coping options have been generated, the client will need to decide on a specific plan of action. Questions can be used to guide a process of rational decision-making (Beck et al. 1993). Throughout the deci- sion-making process, the client always retains the respon- sibility for deciding on the preferred plan of action. The therapist helps to encourage the client’s self-evaluation of problems, goals, and effective coping options. During the efforts to generate a wide variety of coping options, critical judgment should be postponed in an effort to encourage creativity in the approach to the problems. During the decision-making stage, critical evaluation assumes a cen- tral role. Clients are encouraged to realize that every choice has consequences. Even procrastination becomes a choice, with inaction being the unfortunate but inevitable result. Early in the decision-making process, clients can be helped to eliminate any options that appear obviously ineffective, potentially dangerous, or unlikely to be successful in reaching the client’s goal.
Clients can be assisted in the self-evaluation process, examining the advantages and disadvantages of different options, anticipating the short-term and long-term conse- quences for self and others. Useful questions include: ‘‘What have you been doing to cope with this problem?, ‘‘How well has that been working for you?’’; ‘‘Based on everything we have discussed today, what do you think is the best plan?’’; ‘‘What are you ready to do to try to improve this situation?’’;‘‘What will you gain by behaving in that way?’’; ‘‘What might you lose through that strat- egy?’’; ‘‘As we sit here now, what do you think will be the most effective strategy?’’; ‘‘How will that plan affect your family?’’; ‘‘What do you see as the disadvantages of this approach?’’. The therapeutic dialogue can help clients to estimate the personal value of each outcome, in terms of
risks and benefits. When examining different coping options, clients should work to attain the personal and social goals they value most. The discussion can examine the potential benefits of ending a troubled relationship (with a roommate or boyfriend) versus working to improve the quality of the relationship. The value of different out- comes will be influenced by the strategy’s effect on the client as well as on the client’s family and friends. Ques- tions can include: ‘‘How would this strategy play out for you?; ‘‘Do you think this plan will make things better or worse between you and your co-workers?’’; ‘‘How would this plan affect other people in your life?’’.
It can be important to note that different outcomes might be evident at different points in time. Thus, some plans might work well in the short-term, while being counter- productive over a longer period of time. Useful questions can include: ‘‘How will you feel if you put this plan into effect?’’; ‘‘What is likely to be the first change you notice?’’; ‘‘How would this strategy play out over a longer period of time?’’; ‘‘What do you think would be your best plan of action?’’; ‘‘Realistically, what can you do this week that might help you move one step closer toward your goal?’’; ‘‘If we try to break out of a rut and think outside the box, what else could you try?’’. Clients can focus on plans and preparation instead of their emotional reaction to problems.
Clients can learn to anticipate the probability of reach- ing the goal via different options. Some coping options are likely to be effective, while other plans may have a lower probability of success. Clients can learn to anticipate the probability of different outcomes in response to their coping efforts. Questions include: ‘‘What is your best guess
— how effective do you think this plan will be?’’. Many clients benefit from learning to anticipate their coping efforts, struggles, and likely consequences of their actions. Guided discovery includes letting clients make their own decisions, even when the client’s choice differs from the therapist’s selection. Sometimes, clients need to learn from their mistakes. However, it is equally important to help steer clients away from illegal acts (e.g., acts of sexual exhibitionism) or dangerous behaviors (e.g., suicide attempts).
Clients can be asked to calculate the effort required in order to put the plan into effect. Even when an ideal plan is available, it will not work if it requires too much effort from the client. Before therapy moves forward, the best coping options should be evaluated in terms to the effort required for clients to implement the plan. Useful questions include: ‘‘How easy or hard would it be for you to put this plan into effect?’’; ‘‘If you really hope to improve your marriage, what kinds of things are you willing to change?’’; ‘‘What might make it difficult to work though this plan?’’; ‘‘Is there anything we can do to improve your chances of

We conducted repeated-measures mixed effects model analyses for the primary outcome (Functional Independence Measure) and the exploratory outcomes (inhibition, cognitive flexibility). Repeated-measures mixed model analyses allow for missing data without impu- tation. We examined group (strategy training, attention con- trol) and time (baseline, discharge, 3, and 6 months) as main fixed effects, including the group * time interaction and significant baseline characteristics as covariates. We exam- ined group variances and allowed the residual matrix to have different variances for each group when necessary. The optimal fit model was selected by comparing the Bayesian criterion between nested models. Post hoc analy- ses were completed using planned contrasts in the repeated- measures mixed models to interpret significant fixed effects. All available data were used in analyses for the first pass, and we also completed sensitivity analyses by repeating the mixed models analyses for participants with complete data. For all statistically significant models, Cohen’s d effect sizes were computed using model-derived change score estimates.', 'Meta-cognitive strategy training (hereafter referred to as strategy training) is an intervention designed to harness one’s ability to observe, assess, and positively alter one’s own behavior.1 Strategy training teaches individuals to identify and prioritize problematic daily activities, identify barriers impeding performance, generate and evaluate strat- egies addressing these barriers, and generalize learning through practice.1,2 Thus, strategy training teaches skills that can be used to address disability in “real-life” activities, and it is therefore worth considering in rehabilitation.
The hallmark of strategy training is its delineation between the therapist’s role and the participant’s role in the rehabilitation process. Therapists assume a role of guided discovery,3 systematically facilitating participants’ learn- ing through prompts and questions rather than directly
instructing participants. In doing so, therapists guide par- ticipants, allowing participants to learn through their expe- riences. Through strategy training, participants learn to work through or work around specific problems in selected daily activities. In addition, participants learn how to apply the process to novel activities and situations, with the goal of promoting additional recovery of independence with daily activities long after rehabilitation is completed.

Strategy training has been examined in a variety of clini- cal populations (eg, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, learning disability, major depressive disorder, acquired brain injury) as an intervention to address a variety of clinical out- comes (eg, independence, productivity, self-regulation).4-10 Originally conceived as a method for self-monitoring,11 strat- egy training has been examined as an intervention for teach- ing problem-solving skills.12,13 In fact, selected studies suggest that strategy training helps adults with acquired brain injury (ie, stroke, traumatic brain injury) reduce disabil- ity,1,2,14,15 and may even address some of the cognitive sequelae, particularly impairments in executive cognitive functions, associated with acquired brain injury.16,17
These studies have examined strategy training in clinical populations with stable behavioral and cognitive symp- toms, including individuals with acquired brain injury in the chronic phase of recovery. However, there are compelling reasons to suspect that strategy training administered in the acute phase of recovery may have a robust effect on long- term outcomes. Experience-dependent synaptic changes that occur in the acute phase are likely to shape subsequent trajectories of recovery.18,19 These trajectories of recovery establish patterns of behavior, or habits, that are difficult to change.20 This is important because even small to moderate improvements in behavior can substantially reduce care- giver burden and health care costs.21,22 Furthermore, reha- bilitation programs that have the potential to shape biological and behavioral patterns of recovery are most accessible during the acute phase of recovery. Combined, these factors support early intervention.
We previously examined the rationale for and feasibility of strategy training in adults with acute cognitive impair- ments after acquired brain injury (specifically, adults with stroke).1,2,23 The purpose of this pilot study was to obtain preliminary data estimating the effect of strategy training, relative to an attention control condition, in the acute phase of recovery after stroke. The primary aim was to estimate the effect of strategy training on activities of daily living outcomes. The secondary aim was to explore the effects of strategy training on selected measures of executive cogni- tive functions. Our intent was to use these pilot data, and our experiences, to inform the design of future larger scale clinical trials examining the efficacy of strategy training in acute rehabilitation.']
